official-title.#text: To ensure that the provision of foreign assistance does not contribute to human trafficking and to combat human trafficking by requiring greater transparency in the recruitment of foreign workers.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on
committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

committee-name.#tail: , for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

short-title.#text: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
As used in this Act, the following definitions apply:

term.#tail: means recruiting, soliciting, or related activities with respect to an individual who resides outside of the United States in furtherance of employment in the United States, including when such activity occurs wholly outside of the United States.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means any person who performs foreign labor contracting activity, including any person who performs foreign labor contracting activity wholly outside of the United States, except that the term does not include any entity of the United States Government.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means any natural person or any corporation, company, firm, partnership, joint stock company or association or other organization or entity (whether organized under law or not), including municipal corporations.

text.#text: The term
Except as otherwise specified, the term

term.#tail: means an individual who is the subject of foreign labor contracting activity and does not include an exchange visitor (as defined in

text.#text: The term

external-xref.#tail: of title 22, Code of Federal Regulations, or any similar successor regulation).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended—

header.#text: Ensuring that foreign assistance does not contribute to human trafficking

text.#text: by redesignating

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000/s:106/ss:h

text.#text: by inserting after

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Agency for International Development

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make reasonable efforts to incorporate anti-trafficking and anti-slavery priorities into other aspects of foreign assistance, including the maintenance of systems, such as appropriate supply chain monitoring, to ensure that assistance programs do not contribute to vulnerability to, or the prevalence of, human trafficking and slavery, consistent with this Act.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Prevention of Trafficking in conjunction with foreign assistance

text.#text: Any foreign labor contractor shall ascertain and disclose to each worker in writing in English and in the primary language of the worker at the time of the worker’s recruitment, the following information:

The identity and address of the employer and the identity and address of the person conducting the recruiting on behalf of the employer, including any subcontractor or agent involved in such recruiting.

All assurances and terms and conditions of employment, from the prospective employer for whom the worker is being recruited, including the work hours, level of compensation to be paid, the place and period of employment, a description of the type and nature of employment activities, and any penalties for terminating employment.

An itemized list of any costs or expenses to be charged to the worker and any deductions to be taken from wages, including any costs for housing or accommodation, transportation to and from the worksite, meals, health insurance, workers’ compensation, costs of benefits provided, medical examinations, health care, tools, or safety equipment costs.
A signed copy of the work contract between the worker and the employer.

The type of visa under which the foreign worker is to be employed, the length of time for which the visa will be valid, the terms and conditions under which the visa may be renewed, and a clear statement of any expenses associated with securing or renewing the visa.

Whether and the extent to which workers will be compensated through workers’ compensation, private insurance, or otherwise for injuries or death, including work-related injuries and death, during the period of employment and, if so, the name of the State workers’ compensation insurance carrier or the name of the policyholder of the private insurance, the name and the telephone number of each person who must be notified of an injury or death, and the time period within which such notice must be given.
A statement, in a form specified by the
stating that—

no foreign labor contractor, agent, or employee of a foreign labor contractor, may lawfully assess any fee (including visa fees, processing fees, transportation fees, legal expenses, placement fees, and other costs) to a worker for any foreign labor contracting activity; and
the employer may bear such costs or fees for the foreign labor contractor, but that these fees cannot be passed along to the worker;
explaining that—

no additional significant requirements or changes may be made to the original contract signed by the worker without at least 24 hours to consider such changes and the specific consent of the worker, obtained voluntarily and without threat of penalty; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be a violation of this Act and be subject to the provisions of
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a/p:7/sp:B/cl:i

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:10

text.#text: any significant changes made to the original contract that do not comply with
describing the protections afforded the worker by this section and by

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and any applicable visa program, including—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 202 of the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008

text.#text: relevant information about the procedure for filing a complaint provided for in section 10; and
the telephone number for the national human trafficking resource center hotline number.
Any education or training to be provided or required, including—
the nature, timing, and cost of such training;
the person who will pay such costs;
whether the training is a condition of employment, continued employment, or future employment; and
whether the worker will be paid or remunerated during the training period, including the rate of pay.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall constitute a legal conclusion as to the worker’s status or rights under any labor or employment law.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: Nothing in the disclosure required by

header.#text: Relationship to labor and employment laws

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: . The disclosure required by this section is a document concerning the proper administration of a matter within the jurisdiction of a department or agency of the United States for the purposes of
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: No foreign labor contractor or employer who engages in any foreign labor contracting activity shall knowingly provide materially false or misleading information to any worker concerning any matter required to be disclosed under

header.#text: Prohibition on false and misleading information

text.#text: No employer, foreign labor contractor, or agent or employee of a foreign labor contractor, shall assess any fee (including visa fees, processing fees, transportation fees, legal expenses, placement fees, and other costs) to a worker for any foreign labor contracting activity.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , prior to engaging in any foreign labor contracting activity, any person who is a foreign labor contractor or who, for any money or other valuable consideration paid or promised to be paid, performs a foreign labor contracting activity on behalf of a foreign labor contractor, shall obtain a certificate of registration from the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:6/ss:a/p:2

under

text.#text: Subject to

An employer, or employee of an employer, who engages in foreign labor contracting activity solely to find workers for that employer’s own use, and without the participation of any other foreign labor contractor, shall not be required to register under this section.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , not less frequently than once every year, of the identity of any foreign labor contractor involved in any foreign labor contracting activity for, or on behalf of, the employer, including at a minimum, the name and address of the foreign labor contractor, a description of the services for which the foreign labor contractor is being used, whether the foreign labor contractor is to receive any economic compensation for the services, and, if so, the identity of the person or entity who is paying for the services.

text.#text: Each employer shall notify the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , not less frequently than once every year, of the identity of any subcontractor, agent, or foreign labor contractor employee involved in any foreign labor contracting activity for, or on behalf of, the foreign labor contractor.

providing for consultation with other appropriate Federal agencies to determine whether any reason exists to deny registration to a foreign labor contractor.
Unless suspended or revoked, a certificate under this section shall be valid for 2 years.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall impose a fee, to be deposited in the general fund of the Treasury, on a foreign labor contractor that submits an application for a certificate of registration under this section.

shall refuse to issue or renew, or shall revoke and debar from eligibility to obtain a certificate of registration for a period of not greater than 5 years, after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, a certificate of registration under this section if—

text.#text: In accordance with regulations promulgated by the
the applicant for, or holder of, the certification has knowingly made a material misrepresentation in the application for such certificate;
the applicant for, or holder of, the certification is not the real party in interest in the application or certificate of registration and the real party in interest—
is a person who has been refused issuance or renewal of a certificate;
has had a certificate revoked; or
does not qualify for a certificate under this section;
the applicant for, or holder of, the certification has been convicted within the preceding 5 years of—

any felony under State or Federal law or crime involving robbery, bribery, extortion, embezzlement, grand larceny, burglary, arson, violation of narcotics laws, murder, rape, assault with intent to kill, assault which inflicts grievous bodily injury, prostitution, peonage, or smuggling or harboring individuals who have entered the United States illegally; or
any crime relating to gambling, or to the sale, distribution or possession of alcoholic beverages, in connection with or incident to any labor contracting activities; or
the applicant for, or holder of, the certification has materially failed to comply with this section.

Any bond requirements or the forfeiture of any bond under this subsection are in addition to other remedies under this Act or any other law.

If the court finds in a civil action filed by an individual under this section that the defendant has violated any provision of this Act (or any regulation issued pursuant to this Act), the court may award—

damages, up to and including an amount equal to the amount of actual damages, and statutory damages of up to $1,000 per plaintiff per violation, or other equitable relief, except that with respect to statutory damages—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to determine the amount of statutory damages due a plaintiff; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:3/ss:a

text.#text: multiple infractions of a single provision of this Act (or of a regulation under this Act) shall constitute only 1 violation for purposes of
if such complaint is certified as a class action the court may award—
damages up to an amount equal to the amount of actual damages; and
statutory damages of not more than the lesser of up to $1,000 per class member per violation, or up to $500,000; and other equitable relief;
reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs; and
such other and further relief, including declaratory and injunctive relief, as necessary to effectuate the purposes of this Act.

text.#text: Beginning 180 days after the
An employer shall not have any liability under this section if—

at the time of referral; and

text.#text: each worker claiming harm for any violation of this Act was referred to the employer by a foreign labor contractor that had a valid registration with the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: of any violation of this Act by a foreign labor contractor of which the employer had actual knowledge.

text.#text: prior to the initiation of any complaint or investigation under subsection (a), the employer did not fail to notify the

Foreign labor contractors shall be subject to the provisions of this section for violations committed by the foreign labor contractor’s agents or subcontractors of any level in relation to their foreign labor contracting activity to the same extent as if the foreign labor contractor had committed the violation.

No person shall intimidate, threaten, restrain, coerce, discharge, or in any other manner discriminate or retaliate against any worker or their family members (including a former employee or an applicant for employment) because such worker disclosed information to any person that the worker reasonably believes evidences a violation of this section (or any rule or regulation pertaining to this section), including seeking legal assistance of counsel or cooperating with an investigation or other proceeding concerning compliance with this section (or any rule or regulation pertaining to this section).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may, in a civil action, recover appropriate relief, including reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs, with respect to that violation. Any civil action under this subparagraph shall be stayed during the pendency of any criminal action arising out of the violation.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Fraudulent Overseas Recruitment and Trafficking Elimination Act of 2013/s:10/ss:h/p:1

shall grant advance parole to permit a nonimmigrant to remain legally in the United States for time sufficient to fully and effectively participate in all legal proceedings related to any action taken pursuant to this section.

Nothing in this Act shall be construed to preempt or alter any other rights or remedies, including any causes of action, available under any other Federal or State law.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is authorized to prescribe regulations to implement this Act and to develop policies and procedures to enforce the provisions of this Act.
